Text: 1) Take boring breaks. Text: Very important to note, is that you also need to make ''productive''/''important'' tasks more rewarding for yourself. Simply ''removing'' dopamine from your life (i.e. taking boring breaks, no phone in between things). Is not enough. It makes other (productive) things more stimulating in comparison. But your brain needs a certain level of dopamine and will likely get frustrated if you don''t give it this.   So the advice in the video is good, but you should also try and make your work more rewarding/stimulating. For example by watching videos or reading articles related to the topic to become more interested, or by making sure doing the task feels better, for example by working in a pleasant enviroment or making sure you''re well rested and fed. This will make the task more rewarding and easier. Which will make you more productive, while at the same time making social media etc less appealing.

Text: Here is how you can "reprogram" your dopamine, explained simply: What is Dopamine? Imagine dopamine is the excitement juice or the "more" molecule in your brain. • Dopamine gives you a reward when you do certain activities. It makes you want to do more of whatever gave you that reward. • When you scroll through TikTok or play a video game, your brain gets a huge, easy splash of dopamine. This is called overstimulation. • The problem is that if you get constant, huge splashes of excitement juice (dopamine), your brain gets used to it. Soon, your brain needs more and more stimulation just to feel a little bit rewarded, like needing ice cream, video games, and scrolling all at once. • The work you need to do—like learning a new skill or finishing your homework—can''t compete with that huge splash, so it feels dull and boring. • The goal is to stop needing huge amounts of stimulation to feel rewarded and instead become highly sensitive, so even a nice song or a beautiful sunset feels exciting. You can''t truly "detox" dopamine because it''s a neurochemical your brain needs to function. Instead, you want to master your dopaminergic system by making the boring tasks feel rewarding. 3 Simple Ways to Reprogram Your Dopamine To make hard work feel as exciting as scrolling through social media, you need to follow these three steps: 1. Take "Boring Breaks" When you are working hard and need a break, the natural thing to do is check your phone or social media. But those activities are more stimulating than the work itself, which makes it much harder to go back to the work because your work now feels even duller. • The Rule: Take boring breaks that starve your brain of dopamine. • What to do: Instead of checking your phone, spend five to ten minutes doing something simple and non-stimulating. You could stare at a blank wall, drink a cup of tea, or simply let the thoughts in your head "settle". • Why it works: You want the dopamine-seeking part of your brain to crave getting back to work rather than staying stuck on the fun break activity. When you starve your brain of that easy excitement, going back to your homework feels like a fun reward. 2. Habit the "In Between" We often reach for our phones or look for quick distraction during those small moments when we are waiting for something—like waiting in line, sitting alone at lunch, or commuting. This is unintentional information consumption that fractures your attention. • The Rule: Inhabit the "in between" by tolerating moments without much stimulation. • What to do: When you arrive early to a meeting, sit quietly without your phone. When you are commuting or waiting in line, just pay attention to your breath or surroundings. • Why it works: Allowing yourself to settle in these quiet moments—forcing yourself to be present—makes you more and more sensitive to reward over time. Your brain''s baseline for what feels boring will shift, which is helpful for deep focus. 3. Do Everything One Thing at a Time Your brain is constantly trying to quickly shift between different things, especially when you multitask. • The Rule: Focus on one thing at a time with singular focus. • What to do: When you are eating, just eat. When you are talking to someone, just talk to them. When you are working on a task, just work on that task. If you get a distracting thought, jot it down in a notebook and go right back to the work, rather than acting on the thought. • Why it works: This trains your brain to shift its focus really fast. The faster you can focus on one thing, the more focusing neurochemistry (dopamine) gets funnelled into your system. This increased dopamine makes the focused work feel good and rewarding

But overstimulation can desensitize us to dopamine''s effects.   - To resensitize ourselves to dopamine, we should take boring breaks, inhabit the in-between moments without stimulation, and focus on one thing at a time. This boosts impulse control and makes tasks more rewarding.  - Take breaks that are more boring than your work. Go for a walk, stare at a wall, etc. Don''t distract yourself with your phone.   - Inhabit the in-between moments by just being present instead of constantly seeking stimulation.   - Do one thing at a time with full focus. This strengthens your ability to shift into an attentive state and makes tasks more engaging.  - Mastering your dopamine system this way can make the boring rewarding. You can achieve flow states more easily and turn work into play.  In summary, we should avoid overstimulation, take boring breaks, focus singularly, and resensitize ourselves to dopamine in order to boost productivity, focus, and flow.

Text: STEP-BY-STEP PROTOCOL 1. Take boring breaks that are less stimulating than your work to reset dopamine sensitivity 2. Use wall staring, napping, walking, or mindfulness instead of social media during breaks 3. Inhabit the in-between moments without your phone when waiting in lines or commuting 4. Practice single-tasking by doing one thing at a time with complete focus 5. Lower your stimulation baseline so work becomes as rewarding as scrolling social media  DOPAMINE RESENSITIZATION - Dopamine sensitivity determines how much stimulation you need to feel rewarded and focused - Over-stimulation desensitizes dopamine receptors, requiring more stimulation for the same reward - You can''t detox dopamine but you can resensitize yourself to it through strategic boredom  BORING BREAKS STRATEGY - Take breaks that are less stimulating than your work to reset reward sensitivity - Wall staring, napping, walking, stretching, or mindfulness work better than social media breaks - The goal is to make work feel as easy as scrolling social media by lowering your boredom baseline  INHABIT THE IN-BETWEEN - Use waiting moments (lines, lunch breaks, commuting) without reaching for your phone - Allow yourself to simply settle and be present instead of consuming information - These moments train your brain to tolerate low stimulation and increase reward sensitivity  SINGLE-TASKING MASTERY - Do everything one thing at a time to heighten reward sensitivity - Rapid shifting between default mode network and task positive network improves focus speed - Singular focus trains your brain to access flow states faster and more reliably

Text: I have ADHD, which means my DRD2 gene, which encodes the dopamine D2 receptors on the postsynaptic neurons is mutated, as well as my DAT1, DRD4, VNTR, SNP and noradrenaline transporter genes. To simplify what this means, my brain is either over or under prunes synaptic connections, leading to the mutated DRD2 gene to either over influence the product of dopamine transporters, or under influence it.  When it''s under influencing the production of transporters, less dopamine is able to move from the gland to the postsynaptic cleft, resulting in each action requiring additional neurochemical work since each neuron is going to have to reuptake the neuromodulators they have since less is able to resupply the bunch, leaving less dopamine neurotransmitters to be used throughout the brain(what we call our dull days). When it over influences the production of transporters, we have our hyper focus moments, or just general hyper moments. This mutation to these genes happens in postnatal, and are not influenced by environmental factors. If you happen to have one of these inherited mutated genes from a parent, but it''s recessive, you are at a higher risk of onsetting or aggravating like ADHD traits through environmental factors, but if you don''t have any genetic markers for it, watching Tik Tok isn''t going to "cause" ADHD, or are "vaccines", since they assert these genes in isolated regions of the world where they never had connection to the outside, but still had markers for these mutated genes. First definition of dopamine... Dopamine is never about reward, it is about ANTICIPATION of reward. Yes it is different scenery and it is not mouldable/adjustable just changing habits or way of thinking or doing that/this. etc. This "might" work if you have proper/healthy brain  development, still there are questions due to definitions.  It can work as if you are trying to quit coffee... Not cigarete, not alcohol, not other very addictive stuff... Dopamine is very very very addictive.
